description.narrative: Desarrollo y producción de colorantes naturales en la región del Chocó de Colombia, para las industrias alimenticia, de cosméticos y cuidado personal, bajo las disposiciones del Protocolo de Nagoya
Access to genetic resources for commercial purposes contract signed which includes an operational benefitsharing system

comment.narrative:
1
The access to genetic resources for commercial purposes contract was signed by Colombias Ministry of Environment and Ecoflora in December 2014 In it the parties negotiated the monetary and nonmonetary benefits to the State An ancillary contract was signed between Ecoflora and Cocomacia representing the community on March 2013 this gives Ecoflora access to the biological resource that is owned by Cocomacia

description.narrative: Public presentation of the progress in benefitsharing and distribution indicators

comment.narrative: 3 1 annual

1
The annual meeting with communities to present the progress concerning the agreements was held in February 2015 it was planned for November 2014 but had to be postponed due to security issues in the area The project coordinator the local coordinator a representative of Cocomacia and an Ecoflora representative took part in the activity This meeting was held in one community and the report was delivered to local actors to be disclosed in other communities

description.narrative: Development of natural plant colorants for the food cosmetics and personal care industries
Plant with industrial capacity for production of blue dye

comment.narrative:
100
During the second semester of 2015 Ecoflora installed a vegetables cuttingmachine and an additional conveyor with their respective electrical parts In addition the filter press missing parts were installed improving production efficiency Support equipment table wheel barrow vacuum cleaner have also been purchased and installed Thanks to these developments the plant is now complete It has undergone maintenance in the first trimester of 2016
07 tonyear
3 tonyear

3 tonyear
Ecoflora has reached a production capacity of 3 tonyear according to the tests effectuated in March 2016 During the second semester of 2015 quality procedures were adapted to ensure the safety and quality of the dye Production procedures have also been perfectionnated to adjust to the new material purchased throughout the year Furthermore the laboratory upgrade scheduled for 2015 was completed with the purchase and installation of equipment such as pH meter hygrometer thermo refractometer and associated equipment for operation and safety such as eyeswashing shower computer equipment and support equipment table wheel barrow vacuum cleaner

description.narrative: Increase in national and regional capacity in ABS through negotiating and monitoring benefitsharing agreements
Proposal of a decree or resolution to facilitate the negotiation of monetary benefits between the user of genetic resources and the state for ABS agreements with commercial purposes

comment.narrative: The proposal of a decree or resolution was initially to be elaborated by a team of experts in ABS during 2014 but the activity was postponed to 2015 because the Ministry of the Environment was waiting to have the results of another consultancy that delivered technical and legal guidelines as an input for this one The Terms of Reference were shared with shortlisted experts and we are waiting for the results of the process to hire the experts

description.narrative: Capacity of MADS on access to genetic resources and benefitsharing measured with UNDPs ABS Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative: The activities to develop capacities related to access to genetic resources in entities of the Environmental National System SINA are programmed for 2016 once we have the proposal of a decree or resolution to facilitate the negotiation of monetary benefits between the user of genetic resources and the state for ABS agreements with commercial purposes In the meantime we are cooperating with another GEF project conservation in areas affected by mining and MADS to arrange a meeting with regional environmental authorities to explore the difficulties in issuing permits for the use of nontimber natural resources this is the permit that Codechocó has not given Cocomacia The meeting is planned for the 24th of July confirmation by the regional environmental authorities is pending

description.narrative: Strengthening of a value chain involving sustainable and efficient supply and marketing capabilities for natural dyes
Volume of blue dye sold under international regulations

comment.narrative: 3 tons

0032 tons
Ecofloras main target market is in the US and Europe but they still dont have the FDA and EFSA permits that will allow them to sell the dye in these markets However they have been granted the INVIMA permit to sell the dye in Colombia and they are exploring other markets that have less stringent authorization processes to sell the dye This has allowed them to begin selling the dye before getting the FDA and EFSA permits

description.narrative: Number of producers who benefit from the purchase of the jagua fruit

comment.narrative:
55 families 31 families of producers included in the baseline 24 new families from which jagua was purchased during the period August 2014June 2015
The number of families producers that sell jagua to the initiative vary according to the availability of fruit and they tend to increase as the volumes in jagua demand increase but these havent increased because of the reasons stated before Additionally when the baseline was established the initiative planned to purchase jagua in Antioquia and Chocó because they had a permit to collect jagua for research purposes in both regions The volumes authorized by this permit were completed in 2013 Since Cocomacia was granted a permit to collect jagua for commercial purposes in Antioquia purchases have continued in this territory but purchases to the families in Chocó have been interrupted because the necessary permit has not been granted

description.narrative: Total annual income from jagua fruit producers sold for the production of natural dyes

comment.narrative: 5000 USD

3227 USD using the exchange rate that was used when the project was formulated of 1US1800 COP
The price for jagua fruit agreed with producers is being met however the volumes of purchased fruit are lower than planned as explained before there have only been 6 purchases from August 2014 to June 2015 instead of 13 as originally planned due to difficulties in the commercial relationship with the local commercial platform and in Ecofloras plant Additionally the volumes of each purchase have not increased significantly because pending permits are hindering supply and demand one permit to collect the fruit and permits to sell the dye internationally
Because of this and because of the change in the previous target the Directive Committee approves to set the target of total annual income received by jagua fruit producers at 23945 USD this includes the income that all jagua producers will receive in the last year of the project

description.narrative: Volume of fruit received by ECOFLORA which complies with the environmental sustainability and quality conditions

comment.narrative:
8 ton total volume of jagua
average Dec 2012Aug 2013
83 ton total volume of jagua

7 ton have been purchased during the 13 months of the project December and January are not considered because purchases dont take place during these months The Directive Committee finds it clearer to express this indicator in total volume of jagua instead of an average monthly value thus the baseline would be 8 ton considering a 1ton monthly average between December 2012 and August 2013
Several factors are affecting jagua supply and demand delays with the permits to collect the fruit and permits to sell the dye the fact that the local commercial platform is not operating tension in the commercial relationship between the latter and Ecoflora a suspension in the production in May and June 2015 due to problems installing a machine in Ecofloras plant the problem is now solved Because of these reasons jagua purchases have not been constant jagua was only purchased in 6 months instead of in 13 months as expected In those six months the average monthly purchase has been around 12tons of fruit Additionally the project intends to increase the production capacity of the dye to 3 tons of dye per year since the conversion rate of jagua fruit to dye is 5 this would imply buying 60 tons of jagua fruit in one year running the plant at full capacity Thus Ecoflora will not be able to buy and process 164ton of fruit per month corresponding to 164 tonsx10 months164 tons as set in this target
Because of this the Directive Committee of the project approves to set this target at 83 tons which corresponds to the sum of the baseline volume of fruit purchased before the project started 9 tons and the volume of fruit purchased during the project 74 tons distributed in 2014 2015 and 2016

description.narrative: To apply the Nagoya Protocol provisions on access and benefitsharing through the development of naturebased products benefitsharing and biodiversity in the Chocó region of Colombia
Number of hectares of forests in the Chocó bioregion under sustainable management due to the proper use of Genipa americana for the production of a dye

comment.narrative: 400 ha
500 ha

430 ha The initiative currently harvests jagua in the area where Cocomacia the owner of the biological resource has an environmental permit from Corpouraba With support from the project during the timeframe covered by this report 1st of July 201530th of June 2016 Cocomacia has been able to submit to Corpouraba X reports about the way it is implementing the corresponding managament plan which is supervised by Corpouraba In October 2015 Codechocó finally granted the harvesting permit allowing Cocomacia to harvest in the Chocó department The first harvest in that territory was undertaken in November benefitting to 9 families in 4 communities with satisfactory results in terms of volumes The area in which the harvest was performed is 30ha which corresponds to the increase in the indicator However two unexpected administrative problems emerged concerning the legalization process in Codechocós jurisdiction first the entitys officials ignore the procedures to issue the safe conduct of mobilization for the fruit Second while the project was expecting the safe conduct issued by Codechocó to cost a similar price to that issued by Corpourabá the safe conduct was charged 407525 pesos This represented 15 o the total price of the fruit almost 10 times the amount charged by Corpouraba Under these conditions harvesting jagua in the Choco territory is financially unviable The project the requested MADSs support to resolve this situation with Codechocó and allow for the commercial viability of the initiative An official of MADS interviewed the Director of Codechocó to clarify the situation and find a possible solution the official is monitoring the entity but the latter has not reported any news Until this situation is resolved harvests are only performed in the jurisdiction of Corpourabá to avoid problems of time and cost

description.narrative: Monetary and nonmonetary benefits received by the State and local communities and derived from commercialization of the dye

comment.narrative:
Monetary a State 0 b communities 0
Nonmonetary a State there are no nonmonetary benefits b communities 2647 of agreements fulfilled

Monetary
a State 0 COP
b Communities 13120000 COPmonth
Nonmonetary
a State socialization of good practices with Corpourabá Codechocó and IIAP and institutional strengthening of communities and associations that are providing the biological resource
b communities 100 of agreements fulfilled

The Access to Genetic Resources for commercial purposes contract was signed by the Ministry of the Enviornment and Ecoflora in December 2014 This contains the monetary and nonmonetary benefits that Ecoflora must share with the State An ancillary contract was signed between Ecoflora and Cocomacia representing the community on March 2013 this gives Ecoflora access to the biological resource that is owned by Cocomacia
Monetary
a State 0 COP in compliance with the negotiation between Ecoflora and Colombias Ministry of the Environment in December 2014 in which the State gave Ecoflora a 4year grace period to start paying it a royalty thus Ecoflora will begin to pay Monetary benefits to the State in 2018 b Communities 5818360 COPmonth TO BE ACTUALIZED project average 122185569 COP22 months we exclude December and January from the denominator because jagua purchases do not occur during those months Monetary benefits received by communities include the money producers receive for selling their jagua and the money that is being paid to community members related to the collection of the fruit wages paid to the crew that collects the fruit rental of equipment and payments for associated services Several factors are affecting this target a jagua supply and demand havent grown as expected because the necessary permits have suffered delays as for the case of the Codechoco harvesting permit granted in October 2015 or have not been granted yet as for the case of the permits to sell the dye in USA and Europe b tension between the local commercial platform and the company that produces the dye provoked the temporary suspension of the supply of jagua in 2014 c the local commercial platform only started operating in February 2016 because of this it is not yet producing profits that could be distributed with producers the community organization and local investors Nonmonetary a State Ecoflora socialized a document of good practices relating to sustainability and jagua management and harvesting with Corpouraba Codechoco and Instituto de Investigaciones Ambientales del Pacifico IIAPat the end of the second semester of 2015 b communities according to the evaluation conducted by the coordination of the project in October 2015 the parties are complying with 29 of the agreements these refer to the 34 agreements negotiated during the Consultation process with the community that gave way to the ancillary contract between Ecoflora and Cocomacia The agreements fall in 6 categories 1Training and social programs 2Relations with producers and sourcing agreements 3Trees management and harvest conditions 4Supply contract between Ecoflora and the local commercial platform 5 Administrative and logistical aspects to strengthen the supply chain 6Communication and dissemination of progress in the project Ten agreements are considered in compliance responding to relations with producers and sourcing agreements maintance and identification of jagua trees hiring people to collect the fruits having a local nonbanking correspondant and disseminating information about the Consultation process Four agreements are not complied with hiring people in each community to collect the fruit is not being fullfilled because the volumes of jagua purchases are not high enough the other three were not considered complied at the time of the evaluation because the local commercial platform was not operating and it was Ecoflora who was performing the tasks agreed upon The other 20 agreements are in partial compliance
